course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Foundational Texts in the Humanities
course.description: This course introduces students to foundational texts in the Chinese and Western humanities. In the process, it builds students' skills at close reading, explication and analytical writing, while expanding their understanding of Chinese and Western cultures and civilizations. The course is offered in separate sections, each has its specific values and approach identified by the teacher. Each section may use different texts, either in Chinese or English. Students should review the texts to be used in each section before registration.

Part One: Evil and Human Nature
What does it mean to be human?

Part Two: Ethics and the Good Life
How ought I to live?

Part Three: Doubt and Knowledge
How can I know?

Course Description
This course introduces students to foundational texts in Chinese and Western humanities. Through a close reading (4 to 8 pages per week) and analysis of short selections from classic texts in world philosophies, the course will help build students’ skills at careful reading, interpretation, and argumentation, while expanding understanding of issues and approaches in Eastern and Western philosophy and culture.
Focusing in particular on key Chinese, Indian, and Western sources, we will investigate these three questions: (1) what does it mean to be human? (2) How should I live my life? (3) What can I know? Through background lectures, short videos, close readings, tutorials, and in‐class discussions, the class will examine: (a) the cultural and philosophical ideas and values expressed in these sources and (b) their historical contexts, contemporary relevance, and their significance for comparative and inter-cultural understanding.

Lots of interesting examples are given for elaboration in the lessons. The class is very popular, almost all seats are full in LTA.
reviews.comment_teaching: She is very passionate about teaching, know lots of stuff with good logic skills and mindset. She would admit her mistakes in the quizzes during classes. Students are always welcomed to ask questions after class. She would usually stay for an hour after class to answer questions. Always have interesting discussion with students. TA are also very helpful.
reviews.comment_grading: Mark would be deducted if MC is answered wrongly in the first 4 quizzes as professor said wild guessing is not encouraged. Quizzes are quite hard and the mean is not very high usually. However, some people already have some basic knowledge about logic and usually score really high so the mean would not be low.
reviews.comment_workload: 5 Quizzes and 1 writing project. Have quiz every 2 weeks, lots of reading material although lots of people may not read them but is useful for the quizzes. Writing project is quite easy , 2 people in a group to write some fallacies and explain them clearly.

reviews.author: samuelcps
reviews.comment_content:
Brief introduction on different major philosophers across our history.
No exams, but only quiz in every other tutorial section. Philosophies such as existentialism and religious thoughts will be discussed. As such, it is a fruitful course if you did not take a nap.
reviews.comment_teaching: If you are like me, who really could not withstand a monotonic teacher, then you will sleep through the whole two hours lecture. Seriously, the powerpoints are chaotic and cramped all the content together, making it really difficult to study beforehand nor to revise.
reviews.comment_grading: I am above one SD in the first quiz then below the mean for the remainder. And since quiz takes up 40% of the grading, it supposedly should be a huge blow on my grade. Yet, I got a decent mark on my final essay (25/30), so my final grade is A-. Overall, its pretty good.
reviews.comment_workload: WAY WAY TOO MANY QUIZZES, and the worst part is the content of the quizzes are really difficult, to a point where I am thinking they are trying to be nick-picking. So unless you are confident on your essay writing skills, do not expect you would revise enough, not to mention the overwhelming readings we have to do. Of course you could skip them, BUT THE QUIZZES ARE BASED ON THE READINGS. Furthermore, a lot of the readings provided are scans, so it got a low resolution and make it difficult to read. The century old style of writing does not help either. Do not forget, a lot of philosophers are not rigid scientists, so the writing structures in their work is such a pain to look at. Good luck on revising without looking up the internet.

reviews.author: SHERE
reviews.comment_content: the contents are basically philosophy. If you have the basic philosophical knowledge or you took philosophy before, you will definitely nail it.  Topics mainly are Aristotle, Socrates, Eichmann, common philosophy topics which I studied before. reviews.comment_grading: grading is really good. You can easily get scored from group discussion and replying or commenting a topic on canvas every week guarantee you A/B+. there is no exams only quiz, and all conducted through IPRS.
reviews.comment_workload: no workload at all. only some research before quiz because the slides provided are somehow complicated. only one essay needed in the end of the semester, but not too complicated, only to explain an idea or a topic and make arguments.

reviews.comment_workload: 4 quiz, 1 essay and tutorial, participation. The 4 quiz separate the topics in to 4 parts. Nearly 3-4 lectures for 1 quiz. It is not hard to remember these 3-4 lectures. And the quiz questions is very simple.

reviews.author: Wong123
reviews.comment_content: As one of the only course offered in Cantonese, the course talks about Logic, Fallacies, dilemma etc. It provides students with a way to analyze whether or not a statement is logical. The course content also allows us to think in a logical way.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching method is quite direct. During lectures, the lecturer will talk about all the materials covered in the syllabus. Most of the example used is quite interesting, such as quotes from celebrities our current affairs. There will be a tutorial before every quiz. it is quite useful for those who cannot understand the lecture
reviews.comment_grading: The grading can be quite harsh. There was a total of 5 quizzes through out the semester. Each of them consists of True-or-False question with some short questions occasionally. For each wrong answer in the  True-or-False question, marks will be deducted. Thus the standard deviation for each quiz is relatively high. Scoring an average for each quiz will result in roughly a C+.
reviews.comment_workload: Worldload is not that high for this course.There are not much to memorize for each quiz. The final project is not difficult as well.Since it is only a 1000 word essay, it will not cost you a lot of time to complete.

reviews.author: K. H.
reviews.title: A Rather Difficult Philosophical Course
reviews.comment_content:
NOTE: This review only applies to the course instructed by Professor Nelson, and is NOT applicable to HUMA 1001A.

This course focus on the text written by famous philosophical thinkers in different era and different region, including Mengzi, Arendt, Socrates e.t.c. Refer to the attached document for topics included.

Overall I would consider the content as interesting as it raise questions on the justification of some concepts which we assume to be true, for example why can we assure the knowledge we know must be true? However do note that some concepts involved might be quite abstract and difficult to understand. Also ensure your English proficiency required is quite high for academic reading of philosophical papers or you will suffer from inability to understand the reading materials.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I would describe him as a mediocre professor. His speaks with monotone so people may fall asleep easily in his lecture. However content wise he did make his best attempt to translate the abstract concepts to real-life examples and explain the contents in detail. Overall I would say his strength is in content while his weakness is in his teaching style.

On the other hand, the TA (LAW, Chun Yin) out-stands from most other TA I have met. He gives great details to some difficult concepts in the canvas discussion. He is also very patient in answering students questions, so if you have any confusion about the contents, please feel free to ask him.

P. S. 1. Indeed the professor tried to make the lecture more interactive by raising some questions and expecting students volunteer to answer. However in my point of view, the nature of Hong Kong educational system makes Hong Kong people feel shy to answer questions in class, so only very few responded to his questions.

P. S. 2. The TA is very willing to give advices on the final essay
reviews.comment_grading: Somehow the final grading is quite decent (although I did not know the actual distribution). The grade calculation can be found in the attached document. I got 84% and I got an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is relatively heavy when compared to other courses due to the following reasons:

1. This course requires you to write your opinions about the topics taught in class every week, and there are 'penalty' for the 'deadline fighters' who decided to submit all opinions to the discussion board in the last two weeks.

2. There are 4 quizzes throughout the whole semester, each worth 10%. Since each quiz has 10 questions, equivalently we have 1% per question and the loss of one mark in the quizzes might result in significant change in the final grade. Moreover, some questions in quizzes test the ability to differentiate minor changes in text and traps people easily.

3. This course requires student to write a final essay and write a peer review to the partner. Student who frustrate with words easily may suffer.

For more details, please refer to the attached document.

reviews.comment_teaching:
The lecture given by the professor were quite boring. Each lecture was 2-hour long, and the speaking of the professor was monotone, making me falling a sleep in almost every lesson. Also, he did not explain the abstract concepts quite clear.

However, the teaching of the TA was good. Through canvas discussion, he often explain the flaws of our arguments to us, and willing to give much comments when I was doing my final essay.
reviews.comment_grading:
40%
Four Quizzes
30%
One Critical Essay (~ 1,000 words, max: 1,500 words).
15%
Participation in in-class and online (Canvas) discussions and discussion groups.
10%
Attendance
5%
Written feedback/evaluation of another student’s paper (~250 words).

The grading of this course is quite good. The mean of this course is about 72%. I got 82%, A-. I do not know what the grade is for getting the mean score, but seems to be B.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was a bit high for this course. First, we have to attend all boring lectures. Also, the quizzes were quite difficult. They spend me a lot of time to revise the notes very thoroughly in order to get the men score. The final essay was definitely a disaster. I had to changed my writing plan very frequently, and search for a lot of information. Moreover, we have to discuss on canvas regularly in order to get the participation score.

reviews.author: pipipipi
reviews.comment_content: Focuses on philosophical concepts such as good and evil, reality, time, existence of God, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor and the TA are really nice and responsible as they are always there to help. The professor tried to make the course content more comprehensible and interesting but since it's philosophy, the course content is still quite hard to understand right away. He also tried to invite more students to participate in in-class discussions but only few (non-local) students will join.
reviews.comment_grading: There will be quizzes (PRS MCQ) every 2 weeks, PRS every lesson for attendance, online discussions, bonus points from tutorial attendance, bonus points from answering questions/ participating discussions in lectures, a final essay and peer evaluation. Everything mentioned contributes to the final grade. I think the mean grade in B as I got mean in everything, never said anything in lecture and posted occasionally in online discussions, ended up with a B+.
reviews.comment_workload: There will be quizzes (1 per 2 weeks i think) you need to prepare for. Pay attention in class and read some readings (usually ~50 pages philosophical texts), try to memorize and understand some key concepts and you will be fine. There is nothing you need to prepare for tutorial/ lectures. The final essay is relatively essay if you understand the main arguments for at least 1 topic taught in this course.

reviews.author: GOLDENFISH
reviews.title: A great replacment than 1000
reviews.comment_content: Mostly logic and fallcies, there are also a bit rhetoring but not much. This course(Fall 16-17) is taught in Cantonese, but it will differ. In general the content is useful for research and for future life.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. is humorous, often uses real life experiences and current news to explain, we were encouraged to think and express ideas during class. She was also patient to answer questions even it takes a long time.
reviews.comment_grading: Doesn't need too much time to get above mean. But it's important to revise and understand concepts. Even quizzes are mostly True & False, it can still be tricky.
reviews.comment_workload: Only lectures, quizzes(T&F/Long Q), and an essay within 1000 words. From what I heard from HUMA1000, this course obviously takes less effort. Readings isn't a must but for better understanding.

reviews.author: Dawnya
reviews.comment_content: About logic and different types of fallacies
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Yip is very friendly and kind. She explains the concepts in details and uses many examples for our easier understanding. She welcomes students to ask questions after lessons. A lot of students stayed behind and asked her questions every lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: I would say the grading is average. If you really concentrate on her teaching during lessons and do revision, your grade won't be too low. But you really need to digest thing taught because they are about logic but not solid knowledge that just requires memorization.
reviews.comment_workload: There is a quiz every 2 weeks and an assignment which is a writing project done by 2 students in a group. In addition, there are several readings that students need to read after every lesson.
